questions.question: At what level does the adult larynx end?
questions.explanation: The adult larynx typically ends at the lower border of C6.

questions.question: What is the average final anteroposterior diameter of glottis in women?
questions.explanation: The average anteroposterior diameter of the glottis is 26mm in women and 36 mm in men.Glottis, also known as rima glottidis, is the narrowest part of the laryngeal cavity. It is formed by:Anterior 2/3rd by membranous cords• Posterior 1/3rd by vocal processes of arytenoids.

questions.question: What is the primary function of the larynx?
questions.explanation: The primary function of the larynx is to protect the airway from ingested food and aspiratedmaterials.This is done by the sphincteric action of the larynx.Other important functions are:•Respiration• Phonation•Building up of intra-thoracic pressure.

questions.question: The presence of which structure is responsible for infants to be able to breathesimultaneously while suckling milk?
questions.explanation: The high position of the larynx in infants allows simultaneous breathing while feeding.522The infant's larynx is positioned high in the neck, level of the glottis being opposite to C3 or C4 atrest and reaches C1 or C2 during swallowing. The high position allows the epiglottis to meet thesoft palate and make a nasopharyngeal channel for nasal breathing during suckling.The milk feed passes separately over the dorsum of the tongue and sides of the epiglottis, thusallowing breathing and feeding to go on simultaneously.

questions.question: Which embryological structure develops into the epiglottis?
questions.explanation: The epiglottis develops from the hypobranchial eminence which is a part of the 4th arch.

questions.question: Which of the following comprises the larynx?
questions.explanation: The larynx has 3 unpaired and 3 paired cartilages.Unpaired:• Thyroid• Cricoid• EpiglottisPaired:•• Arytenoid•Corniculate• Cuneiform.

questions.question: The lateral x-ray of an elderly man shows calcification of the laryngeal cartilages. Which ofthe following is unlikely to be involved?
questions.explanation: Epiglottis is unlikely to be calcified as it is made up of elastic cartilage.Only hyaline cartilages can undergo ossification (calcifications on x-ray). It occurs between theages of 25-65y. These calcifications may be confused with foreign bodies of esophagus or larynxon x-rays.The hyaline laryngeal cartilages are:• Thyroid. Cricoid•Most of arytenoid.The elastic laryngeal cartilages are:•⚫ Epiglottis• Corniculate523• Cuneiform• Tip of arytenoid.

questions.question: Which of the following cartilage has a signet ring shape?
questions.explanation: Cricoid cartilage resembles a signet ring. It has a wide posterior lamina and a thin anterior arch.

questions.question: The skeletal remains of a person were found in a nearby forest. The thyroid cartilage wasidentified and the thyroid angle measures 90 degrees. The deceased person can be deemed asa
questions.explanation: The thyroid angle measures 90 degrees (right-angled) in men.It is the angle between the two thyroid lamina in the midline. It depends on gender:• Men: 90 degrees (forms the prominent adam's apple)• Women: 120 degrees.

questions.question: Which of the following is called cartilage of Santorini?
questions.explanation: Corniculate cartilage is also known as the cartilage of Santorini.Cuneiform cartilage is also known as the cartilage of Wrisberg.Body of hyoidboneThyrohyoidmembraneCricothyroidligamentCricotrachealligamentEpiglottisThyrohyoidmembrane.Cuneiform cartilageCorniculate cartilageArytenoid cartilageThyroid cartilage.Cricoid cartilageTracheal cartilagesLarynxAnterior viewRight lateral viewOMARROWEpiglottis-ThyroidcartilageLaryngealprominenceCricoidcartilageTrachealcartilagesBody of hyoid boneHyoepiglottic ligamentPre-epiglottic fatty padVestibular foldVocal foldCricothyroid ligamentCricotracheal ligament

questions.question: An ENT surgeon is operating on the larynx of a patient and he approaches the arytenoidcartilage. Which of the following is false regarding the attachments of the arytenoid cartilage?
questions.explanation: The apex of the arytenoid supports the corniculate cartilages.524The following are the attachments of the arytenoid:• Base cricoid-• Vocal process - vocal ligament• Muscular process - intrinsic muscles of larynx• Apex - corniculate cartilages.

questions.question: Which of the following is not involved in the closure of the glottis?
questions.explanation: The posterior cricoarytenoid opens the glottis as it is the only abductor of the vocal cord. All other muscles close the glottis.

questions.question: An opera singer presents with difficulty raising the pitch of her voice while singing. Which ofthe following muscles is likely to be affected?
questions.explanation: Cricothyroid is likely to be affected.Cricothyroid and vocalis (internal part of thyroarytenoid) are the tensors of the vocal cord whichhelp in raising the pitch of the voice.The external laryngeal nerve is the smaller, external branch. It descends on the larynx, beneaththe sternothyroid muscle, to supply the cricothyroid muscle. The external branch functions totense the vocal cords by activating the cricothyroid muscle, and increasing pitch.

questions.question: You are the ENT resident examining a patient in the wards. On asking him to swallow, you notice the larynx moves upwards. Which of the following muscles is not responsible for this movement?
questions.explanation: The sternohyoid is not responsible for upward movement (elevation). It is a depressor of the larynx. The extrinsic muscles of the larynx can be elevators or depressors. Elevators: Primary elevators act directly as they are attached to the thyroid cartilage and include • Stylopharyngeus • Salpingopharyngeus • Palatopharyngeus • Thyrohyoid. Secondary elevators act indirectly as they are attached to the hyoid bone and include Mylohyoid (main) • Digastric • Stylohyoid • Geniohyoid. Depressors: • Sternohyoid • Sternothyroid • Omohyoid. Easy to remember: Check the other attachment (non-laryngeal side). If it's above the level of the hyoid, the muscle is an elevator. If it's below the level of the hyoid, it's a depressor.

questions.question: Which of the following is an intrinsic membrane of the larynx?
questions.explanation: The cricothyroid membrane is an intrinsic membrane of the larynx as it connects laryngealstructures to each other.Extrinsic membranes and ligaments connect laryngeal structures with surrounding structuresoutside the laryngeal framework like the trachea or hyoid. These are:• Cricotracheal membrane• Thyrohyoid membrane•⚫ Hyoepiglottic ligament.Intrinsic membranes and ligaments connect laryngeal structures with each other. These are:• Cricovocal membrane•Quadrangular membraneCricothyroid ligament• Thyroepiglottic ligament.[Image unavailable][Image unavailable][Image unavailable]

questions.question: 519Following a road traffic accident, a 30-year-old man presents to the emergency departmentwith maxillofacial trauma and inability to open the mouth. To establish an airway, anemergency laryngotomy is performed. Where is the opening made?
questions.explanation: In laryngotomy, an opening is made on the cricothyroid membrane.Laryngotomy is also called cricothyrotomy or mini-tracheostomy. It is done as an emergencylife-saving procedure to buy some time to allow a patient to be carried to the operation theatre.Once stable, it is replaced by intubation or tracheostomy.Most of the laryngeal foreign bodies are arrested above the vocal cords, i.e. above the middle ofthe thyroid cartilage. Thus, an effective airway can be provided by piercing the cricothyroidmembrane.526

questions.question: Which of the following is not seen as part of the larynx?
questions.explanation: Labyrinth is seen in inner ear and not in larynx.The 2 mucosal folds within the larynx divide the larynx into 3 cavities:• Vestibule: Above the false/vestibular folds•• Ventricle: Between the vestibular and vocal/true folds•Subglottis: Below the true foldsSaccule an extension of ventricle is present in the paraglottic space.Interior of the larynxCoronal section-Posterior viewQuadrangularmembraneThyroidcartilageCricovocalmembraneCricoidcartilageMARROWVestibularligament(false vocalcord)Vocalligament(true vocalcord)

questions.question: A surgeon is worried about the spread of laryngeal carcinoma to the pre-epiglottic space.Which of the following structures do not border this space?
questions.explanation: Suprahyoid epiglottis does not form a boundary of the pre-epiglottic space. The infrahyoidepiglottis forms the posteromedial border.Two potential spaces within the larynx provide an avenue for the spread of tumors:.Pre-epiglottic space•Paraglottic space.The pre-epiglottic space is bounded:• Superiorly by the hyoepiglottic ligament••Anteriorly by the thyroid and thyrohyoid membranePosteromedially by the infrahyoid epiglottis and quadrangular membrane.The paraglottic space is bounded:• Laterally by thyroid•Medially by ventricle and quadrangular membrane527• Inferomedially by conus elasticus• Posteriorly by pyriform sinus.Body of hyoidboneThyrohyoidmembraneCricothyroidligament.Cricotrachealligament.EpiglottisCuneiform cartilageCorniculate cartilageArytenoid cartilageThyroid cartilageCricoid cartilageTracheal cartilagesLarynxAnterior viewRight lateral viewOMARROWEpiglottisThyroidcartilageLaryngealprominenceCricoidcartilage-TrachealcartilagesBody of hyoid boneHyoepiglottic ligament∙Pre-epiglottic fatty padThyrohyoid membraneVestibular foldVocal foldCricothyroid ligamentCricotracheal ligament

questions.question: A 35-year-old smoker presents with hoarseness of voice. On laryngoscopy, there is edema ofthe Reinke's space. Where is this space located?
questions.explanation: Reinke's spacecords.is seen in the glottis. It is a potential space underneath the epithelium of vocalIt contains scanty subepithelial connective tissue. Edema of this space is commonly seen insmokers and is called Reinke's edema or smoker's larynx.The laryngoscopy image below shows diffuse bilateral edema of the vocal folds or Reinke's edema.65Hz 51dB528

questions.question: You are performing a direct laryngoscopy procedure to enter the larynx and visualise thestructures it contains. Which of the following structures form the inlet of the larynx?
questions.explanation: Aryepiglottic folds form the inlet of the larynx.The laryngeal inlet is an oblique opening with the following boundaries:• Anterior: Free margin of the epiglottis•Posterior: Interarytenoid fold• Sides: Aryepiglottic folds.

questions.question: Which of the following muscle causes opening of laryngeal inlet?
questions.explanation: Thyroepiglotticus causes the opening of the laryngeal inlet.The intrinsic muscles of the larynx acting on the laryngeal inlet are:•Openers of laryngeal inletThyroepiglottic•Closers of laryngeal inlet• Interarytenoid (oblique part).• Aryepiglottic (posterior oblique part of interarytenoids).529
